0.title: Babel
Airlock: (Unhappy people are hammering on the airlock door  as O'Brien's assistants work frantically)
Look, save your energy. We'll have you out of there as soon as  possible. I hope. Try re-routing the power coupling.
See if you can activate the interlock servos.
Captain Jaheel, those people have been stuck in that airlock  for over an hour. Now if you can wait until we get that door opened,  I'll be happy to listen to any problems you might have.
But I've already been waiting two days for your people to  readjust my ship's antimatter flow converter.
I'm afraid we've gotten a little bit behind in our maintenance  schedule.
I'm not interested in hearing excuses. I have a shipment of  Tamen Sasheer waiting to be delivered to Largo  Five, and I'll need to do better than warp one to get there before it  spoils.
I'll try to get a repair crew to you by the end of the day.  Now that's the best I can do.
Your best, Mister O'Brien, hardly seems good enough.
Can you spare a minute, Chief? I have a little problem here  at the lab.

1.title: Babel
Outside the lab: What are you doing out here?

2.title: Babel
Laboratory: Have you checked the EPS convertor?
Then it's probably the secondary phase modulator. We had  trouble with them last week in the main power core.  That should do it.
(the noise stops, along with the rest of the powered systems)

3.title: Babel
Ops: The navigational computer hasn't been working  reliably for three days. I ask for the star charts of the Argosian  sector, Glessene sector comes up instead. That's when I can coax this  system online.
(under the console) Uh-huh. Try it now.
That's more like it. You look like you could use some sleep.
Who has time for sleep? I'd settle for five minutes of peace  and quiet.
(Sisko gets a drink from the replicators and it is awful)
Chief, I thought you were going to fix the replicators.

5.title: Babel
Corridor: (He comes out and tries the replicator panel.  there's an energy discharge, then it returns to normal)

6.title: Babel
Quark's: Tell me, Quark, am I mistaken or is business a  little slow today?
Slow? It's been almost nonexistent for the past three days.
Who knows, if things don't improve you may be forced to close  down.
Let's just say, without you around my job would be considerably  easier.
Without me around, you'd be forced to find some other, poor  innocent to persecute. Think about that while you sit here gloating at  my misfortune.
Quark! You call this Kohlanese stew?
If your meal isn't satisfactory I'm sure we could exchange it  for something more to your liking.
Aren't you the least bit curious as to how it tastes?
Now, you served it, you're going to eat it.
(A painful shoulder grip sends Asoth on his way)
It's these replicators. If I don't get them fixed soon, they'll  destroy my business.
Why not get O'Brien to fix them? He has the replicators on the  command level working perfectly.
I'm on his waiting list. He assures me he'll get to them as soon  as he can.
No telling when that will be. The Chief's a very busy man.
Computer, display a station layout. Highlight locations of all  repaired replicators on command level.
Information restricted to security clearance five and above.  Please enter security verification.
(Quark selects two rods from a selection in the drawer and inserts  them.)

7.title: Babel
Ops: There you go, sir. I think you'll find  that more to your liking.
Don't mention it, sir. Unfortunately, there are plenty of  replicators around the station that still need looking after.
I'm just a bit hot. The environmental controls must be acting  up again.
Send my regards to Mrs O'Brien. Jake tells me she's a wonderful  teacher.
That's nice to hear, sir. She's flower units about the lad  herself.
What was that you just said?
She's quite fond of the lad herself.

8.title: Babel
Promenade: I forgot how different it was.
Being female. I haven't been one for over eighty years. All this  attention.
I imagine it must take some getting use to.
Actually I find it quite enjoyable.
I'd be honoured to have you join my little party. As my guests,  of course.
What's all this, Quark? You cheat your one thousandth customer?
Who says Bajorans don't have a sense of humour? Actually, we're  celebrating the repair of the bar's replicator system. Perhaps I could  interest you in a nice double whipped Idanian spice pudding.

9.title: Babel
Quark's: Please, make yourself comfortable,  Lieutenant. I did say a double whipped spice pudding, didn't I?
It's lovely. I almost hate to eat it.

10.title: Babel
Ops: How can I help you, Major?
You're the one who could use a little help.
I suppose this isn't a good time to tell you that number three  turbolift has broken down again. Joking, Chief.
Let birds go further loose maybe. Shout easy play.
Chief, you're not making any sense.
Round the turbulent quick. Well, close the reverse harbour.  Ankle try sound. Reset gleaming. Dinner to bug.

11.title: Babel
Infirmary: (O'Brien is having his eyesight checked,  apparently)
Computer, continue neural imaging scan and stimulate visual  cortex.
No physiological damage. All brain functions within normal  parameters.
Will you pull up Mister O'Brien's neurophysiological history,  please?
(O'Brien grabs a PADD and starts tapping on it)
What is that? What's he written?
(The PADD says 'Flame the dark true, salt way link, complete strike,  limits victory, frosted wake, simple hesitation)
Strike limits. Flame the dark true salt.
(Kira pushes him back onto the bed)

He appears to be suffering from a form of aphasia. It's a  perceptual dysfunction in which aural and visual stimuli are  incorrectly processed by the brain. His actual thinking hasn't been  affected, but he's incapable of expressing himself or understanding  others.

12.title: Babel
Ops: I'm not sure I follow you, Doctor. You say  Mister O'Brien is aphasic, but all of his tests come up negative.
Isn't aphasia typically associated with some kind of cranial  trauma?
Yes. It can occur as a result of a stroke or blow to the head.  But there's no evidence of that here.
Did you check the medical library for any precedents?
Find one. Major Kira, get hold of the Chief's personal duty log.  I want to know where he's been and what he's done for the past fifty  two hours.
I've already examine it, Commander. He's been all over the  station.
Retrace his steps and see what you come up with. Dax, you will  temporarily assume Mister O'Brien's duties.
Is there a problem, Lieutenant? Lieutenant?

13.title: Babel
Infirmary: Spontaneous development of aphasia is  virtually impossible. Yet we saw Lieutenant Dax become aphasic before  our eyes. This told me we are dealing with a disease that only mimics  aphasia. So I ran a full neurosynaptic comparison of Dax and O'Brien,  and I found this in the temporal lobes of both patients.

It imposes itself within the established synaptic pathways and  then randomly reroutes them. For example, when I look at this, (holds  up a tricorder) a process occurs in my brain which connects the  stimulus to the word tricorder. This virus disrupts that process.
I'd see a tricorder but I would say something ridiculous like  window.
Doctor, I think you should get over here.
View lost pile luck. Away tunnel back the garden.
Doctor, I want this station put under emergency quarantine  immediately.

14.title: Babel
Quark's: (Odo comes out of his office to an empty Promenade  but a noisy bar)
Quark, what is going on here?
It looks like business as usual, but that's impossible because all  shops and business have been closed until further notice.
Except, of course, for essential station operations.
For which this place hardly qualifies.
I don't think they'd agree. This quarantine has everybody on  edge, Constable. Would you deprive them of a little harmless diversion?
They'd be safer in their quarters.
Fortunately, my assistant Rom, was able to fix the replicators.

15.title: Babel
Promenade upper level: Jake! I expected you home an hour ago.
Sorry. I was at Nog's. (they go down the stairs) Dad, about this  quarantine, it's going to be okay, isn't it?

16.title: Babel
Promenade: I wish I shared your confidence Commander.
Go straight home, son. I'll see you at dinner.
Captain Jaheel, all visitors have been confined to their ships.
Believe me, there is no place I'd rather be.
Then what are you doing here?
Commander, I officially request permission to leave this  station.
But none of my crew has been affected by this virus of yours,  and unless I depart at once my whole cargo will be ruined.
Captain, I suggest you return to your ship now.
Please. I don't want to get sick.

17.title: Babel
Empty quarters: (Quark lets himself into the room with a food  trolley and goes to the replicator)
Computer, let's start with one Ferengi starduster, please. Extra  strong. Perfect.
I thought the front wheels were sticking a bit.
Unauthorised access to crew quarters is a crime, Quark. You could  have just asked to use the replicators.
There's an old Ferengi saying. Never ask when you can take. How  did you figure it out?
You claimed Rom fixed your replicators.
Rom's an idiot. He couldn't fix a straw if it was bent.

18.title: Babel
Ops: Based on the levels of the virus found in  the patients' blood, I believe it's being absorbed through ingestion.
You're saying it's in our food?
That's not possible. All the food on the station is replicated,  and all the replicators use biofilters. They automatically screen out  contaminants including viruses.
Major, I've analysed samples from replicators all over the  station. Food on the command level is contaminated.
But all of us here have eaten from those replicators. How come  we're not aphasic?
This virus is highly adaptable. Its incubation period seems to  vary within each individual.
According to O'Brien's duty log, the last thing he did before  become aphasic was fix the command level replicators.
Get a repair crew over there to inspect the site. Let's shut  down those replicators. Maybe we'll be able to limit further  contamination.
I'm afraid that's not going to do it, sir. I've been getting  aphasic patients from all over the station.
You can thank Quark. I caught him using a replicator in one of the  vacant crew quarters. He was producing his entire menu out of there.
If this virus is present within a large enough segment of the  population, it could mean
I just took an air sample.
(Puts his tricorder results on a monitor)
It's mutated into an airborne variety.

20.title: Babel
Commander's office: I found it inside the replicator's pattern  generator.
O'Brien must have accidently triggered it when he repaired the  system.
According to Bashir, it introduced an anomalous programming  sequence into the materialisation subroutine. In effect, it built the  virus directly into the replicated food at a molecular level.
So what we have here is sabotage.
It has a diboridium core for a power source. That is Cardassian  technology.
Commander, I think you'd better get down here to the  Infirmary, as soon as possible.

21.title: Babel
Infirmary: You wanted to see me, Doctor?
Left, become better, control, entire hope.
We've converted some empty crew quarters into a hospital ward.  He'll be well looked after.
I'll take him there myself. Come on, Jake. You're going to be  all right.

22.title: Babel
Hospital ward: It'll be fine. Just lay back. I know, but  just lay back and relax.
Food. Dabo. Drinks. Money. Hand. Mine. Give.
Well, Quark, I see even you couldn't weasel your way clear of  this one.
You underestimate the Ferengi immune system, Commander. I'm  merely here visiting  my less fortunate customers to make sure they're not faking the illness  to avoid paying their bills.
I am. You gold owe me. I now give.
(They find Jake a bed next to Dax and O'Brien)

23.title: Babel
Infirmary: The virus is synthetic, Commander. Its  nucleotide sequence is too perfect. It's clearly not natural.
You're saying the Cardassians genetically engineered this thing?
Well that's what I thought at first, but I've studied  Cardassian genetic engineering. They always build distinctive  monoclonial links into their DNA. This virus has none of those  features.
All right then, who made it.
That's what I wanted to find out. So I referenced all known DNA  construction techniques in the Federation records, and this protein  series was the key. It indicates that

24.title: Babel
Commander's office: The energy decay of this power core indicates  that it dates back to the building of the station.
That's eighteen years ago. I suppose the Bajoran underground could  have smuggled it aboard during construction, before I took over as Head  of Security.
But why would the underground go to all the trouble of planting  a booby trap and not set it off?
No. More likely they were captured or killed before they could  release it.
We need to find out who created this virus. You're our best  hope.
Eighteen years is a long time.
Besides, even if she finds who did this, that's no guarantee they  can help us.
We just have to hope they remembers the antidote.

25.title: Babel
Ops: Had to be someone in the underground familiar  with genetic engineering.
Eighteen years ago. Sounds like something Dekon  Elig might have thought up.
The last I heard he was in a Cardassian prison.
The Velos Seven Internment Camp. But that was nine years ago.
And you have no idea where he is now? Think, Galis. This is  important.

26.title: Babel
Hospital ward: Roll linger when life. Roll linger when.
(Dax puts the nurses hand on O'Brien's forehead)

27.title: Babel
Infirmary: Not good, I'm afraid. The virus has attacked his autonomic  nervous system.
He hasn't responded to neural stimulation. I've given him  thirty cc's of corophizine to avoid secondary infection, but so far  I've been unable to lower his fever.
Unless I find some way to counteract the virus, he'll be dead  in twelve hours.

No. I've tried base pair destabilisers, sequential disruption,  nothing seems to affect it. Sir, I've got seven other aphasic patients  displaying the same symptoms as O'Brien here, and I'm afraid this is  only the beginning.
Keep searching, Doctor. I hope Major Kira can find whoever's  responsible for creating this virus.
I'd like to meet that person myself. This virus is a work of  genius.

28.title: Babel
Ops: Link established with the Bajoran  Archival Records.
Locate files on Velos Seven Internment camp.
Do you show a record of an inmate named Dekon Elig?
Dekon Elig. Geneticist. Former member of the Higa Metar Sect  of the Bajoran underground. Killed while attempting escape stardate  39355. Certificate of Death on file.
No need to ask how you're doing.
You have twelve hours to catch one.
Computer, display Dekon Elig's Certificate of Death. Identify  signature of witness.
Certificate of Death was witnessed by Surmak Ren, Bajoran  Medical Assistant.
Show me biographical data on Surmak Ren.

29.title: Babel
Quark's: (Empty, so Quark is playing dabo on his own.)
I haven't won a spin in hours. Care to place a friendly wager?  If it's your reputation you're thinking about no one need ever know.
It has nothing to do with my reputation. The truth is, I never  learned the game.
You mean, you've sat here for all these years and you don't even  know how to gamble?
No wonder you always look so bored. The rules are quite simple,  actually. I'd be happy to show them to you.
Some other time perhaps. Sisko needs me in Ops. And since the  entire security force stricken with aphasia, the Promenade in a very  vulnerable position.
Consider it a warning, Quark, because I'm holding you personally  responsible if anything turns up missing. Is that understood?

30.title: Babel
Infirmary: Computer, analyze test sample thirty seven  delta. Detail effects on viral containment.
Working. Analysis complete. Sample thirty seven delta  ineffective. Viral protein sheath is unaffected. Nucleotide sequence  remains intact
Glass lunch judge a bin to let it

31.title: Babel
Ops: Computer, establish link with the Bajoran  Medical Index for the Northwestern District.
Access all information on Doctor Surmak Ren.
There are no records matching that name.
Try the Northeastern District, same search.
Doctor Surmak Ren, currently serving as Chief Administrator  of the Ilvian Medical Complex.
Computer, open a channel to the Ilvian Medical Complex.  Administrators office.
This is Doctor Surmak. And you are?
Major Kira Nerys. Bajoran liaison to Deep Space Nine.
Ah yes, the old Cardassian mining station. How can  I help you?
On whether or not you helped Dekon Elig plant an aphasia virus  here eighteen years ago.
I have no idea what you're talking about.

32.title: Babel
Commander's office: Look, Sisko. I'm a security officer, a good  one, but that doesn't make me qualified to help you run station  operations.
You're probably right, Constable, but as you can see, you're all  I've got.
Commander? Commander, I think I found our scientist.
I don't know. He broke the connection the minute I mentioned the  virus.
Major, you mind telling me where you're going?
To continue my conversation with Doctor Surmak in person.
Major, I can't allow you to break quarantine. We can't risk  spreading the virus to Bajor.
I am well aware of that, Commander. As a matter of fact, I don't  intend to step foot on the planet.
Better let her go, Sisko. She's all we've got.

34.title: Babel
Ops: You'd better take a look at this. We have  activity on docking port five. I think a ship is about to depart.
Docking port five? That's Jaheel's ship. Put him on screen.  Captain, your ship has not been cleared for departure. The mooring  clamps are locked and I don't intend to release them.
I suggest you change your mind. I'm taking aft  thrusters to one half.
Captain, cut your engines before you rip your ship apart.
Jaheel, I'm ordering you to stand down.
Your orders are no concern of mine. My entire  crew has been confined to your hospital. I must leave now while I can  still function.
Look, I understand you're frightened, but believe me, you're  better off here. You don't want to be out there alone and get hit by  the virus.
Don't worry about me. I'm fine, and I plan to  stay that way. And if you think you're going
We'll have to retract the clamps. Once he's clear of the station  we can grab him with a tractor beam. Damn.
There's too much stress on the mooring clamps. They're not  retracting.
His main power core's been ruptured. If the internal fuel cells  collapse the whole ship will explode.

35.title: Babel
Runabout: Computer, isolate a comm. line to the Ilvian  Medical Complex, Administrator's office.
Lock on and stand by to transport.
Hello again, Doctor. Just checking to see you're in your office.
I have nothing to say to you
(And as he stands up Kira beams him aboard the runabout)
This is outrageous. I demand you return me to my office  immediately.

36.title: Babel
Ops: Try to re-establish visual contact with  Jaheel's ship.
No response. His comm. lines are down.
Bypass communications through a secondary grid. See if you can  switch to external pickups.
(A burning bridge is on the viewscreen)
His fire control systems don't appear to be working.
We have about fifteen minutes before the fuel cells collapse.
I hope you feel better than you look.
It must be that damn virus. This is Sisko. Any station personnel  who can understand what I'm saying come to Ops immediately. We need  help up here. We have to get that ship away from the station.
Why don't we explode the mooring clamps. The blast should push the  ship away from the docking ring.
We'll have to get down there and blow them manually.
All right. You can cross barrels. All job appalled.

37.title: Babel
Runabout: Major, this is kidnapping. Turn this ship  around or I swear you'll spend the rest of your life in Kran-Tobol  Prison.
Fine. But first we need your help. The aphasia virus is spreading  through the station.
You helped create the virus, didn't you?

No, I had practically nothing to do with it. Dekon Elig created  the virus. I was merely his medical assistant. That seems like a  lifetime ago now. I was only in the underground for six months before  we were captured. I am not responsible for this.
I am not looking to place blame. All I want is the antidote.
I don't know of any antidote. If Dekon made one, he never told  me.
Listen, Surmak. I have a station full of dying people, and you  are the closest thing there is to an expert on this virus.
I sympathise, Major. But I don't think I can help you.
All right. Then how about helping yourself?

38.title: Babel
Ops: To anyone who can hear me. This is Odo.  Sisko's infected. I could really use some help here in Ops.
Do I detect a note of panic in your voice?
Quark, am I to believe you're volunteering to help?
Who said anything about volunteering? We can haggle over price  later. Now, how may I be of use?
I need to get to docking port five now. That ship's going to  explode in five minutes.
Relax. I served on a Ferengi freighter for eight years.
I must have witnessed the procedure hundreds of times.
Witnessed? You mean to say you never handled the controls  yourself?

39.title: Babel
Runabout: Kira to Ops. Approaching landing pad seven.  Request clearance to initiate docking procedure.
Welcome back. I could use some help up here.

40.title: Babel
Infirmary: First thing I need to see is your Doctors'  viral characterisation research. He was beginning to develop an  antidote series. Let's take a look at that.
Listen, Doctor, I'll be in Ops. If you need me use this string  impact. Lot show red intense.

41.title: Babel
Docking port five: (Jaheel is on the floor with his ship on fire  behind him. Odo hauls him through the airlock to safety)

48.title: Babel
Docking port five: (Odo jettisons the ship and it is hurled away to go KaBOOM at a safe  distance, although somehow the shockwaves manage to travel through  vacuum to the station)

52.title: Babel
Docking port five: Odo drags Jaheel to his feet)

53.title: Babel
Ops: Good to have you back, Chief.
